TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi sealed beforefieldinit LinearGradientBrush extends System.Drawing.Brush

Docs.summary: Encapsulates a with a linear gradient. This class cannot be inherited.

remarks.format:
## Remarks This class encapsulates both two-color gradients and custom multicolor gradients.
All linear gradients are defined along a line specified either by the width of a rectangle or by two points.
By default, a two-color linear gradient is an even horizontal linear blend from the starting color to the ending color along the specified line. Customize the blend pattern using the <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.Blend> class, the <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.LinearGradientBrush.SetSigmaBellShape%2A> methods, or the <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.LinearGradientBrush.SetBlendTriangularShape%2A> methods. Customize the direction of the gradient by specifying the <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.LinearGradientMode> enumeration or the angle in the constructor.
Use the <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.LinearGradientBrush.InterpolationColors%2A> property to create a multicolor gradient.
The <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.LinearGradientBrush.Transform%2A> property specifies a local geometric transform applied to the gradient.
## Examples The following example creates a horizontal LinearGradientBrush; the color components change linearly as you move from a horizontal coordinate of 0 to a horizontal coordinate of 200. For example, a point whose first coordinate is halfway between 0 and 200 will have a blue component that is halfway between 0 and 255. This example is designed for use with Windows Forms. The following code example is designed for use with Windows Forms, and it requires the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs>`e`, which is a parameter of <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventHandler>.
[!code-vb[System.Drawing.UsingaGradientBrush#21](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/t-system.drawing.drawing_3_1.vb)] [!code-cs[System.Drawing.UsingaGradientBrush#21](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/t-system.drawing.drawing_3_1.cs)]

A enumeration element that specifies the orientation of the gradient. The orientation determines the starting and ending points of the gradient. For example, specifies that the starting point is the upper-left corner of the rectangle and the ending point is the lower-right corner of the rectangle.

Docs.param: A structure that specifies the bounds of the linear gradient.
A structure that represents the starting color for the gradient.
A structure that represents the ending color for the gradient.
The angle, measured in degrees clockwise from the x-axis, of the gradient's orientation line.
Docs.summary: Creates a new instance of the class based on a rectangle, starting and ending colors, and an orientation angle.

remarks.format:
## Remarks All points along any line perpendicular to the orientation line are the same color.
The starting line is perpendicular to the orientation line and passes through one of the corners of the rectangle. All points on the starting line are the starting color. Then ending line is perpendicular to the orientation line and passes through one of the corners of the rectangle. All points on the ending line are the ending color.
The angle of the orientation line determines which corners the starting and ending lines pass through. For example, if the angle is between 0 and 90 degrees, the starting line passes through the upper-left corner, and the ending line passes through the lower-right corner.

MemberSignature.Value: public System.Drawing.Drawing2D.Blend Blend { get; set; }
.property instance class System.Drawing.Drawing2D.Blend Blend

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a that specifies positions and factors that define a custom falloff for the gradient.
Docs.value: A that represents a custom falloff for the gradient.

remarks.format: ## Remarks A <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.Blend> contains corresponding arrays of blend factors and positions. The blend factors specify the percentages of the starting color and ending color to use at the corresponding position. The positions are given as a percentage of distance along the gradient line.

MemberSignature.Value: public override object Clone ();
.method public hidebysig virtual instance object Clone() cil managed

Docs.summary: Creates an exact copy of this .
Docs.returns: The this method creates, cast as an object.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following code example is designed for use with Windows Forms, and it requires <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs>`e`, an <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form.OnPaint%2A> event object. The code performs the following actions:
- Creates a new <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.LinearGradientBrush>.
- Draws an ellipse to the screen using this brush.
- Clones the <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.LinearGradientBrush> (`clonedLGBrush`).
- Draws an ellipse to the screen directly below the first ellipse, using the cloned brush.
[!code-vb[System.Drawing.Drawing2D.ClassicLinearGradientBrush#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/m-system.drawing.drawing_18_1.vb)] [!code-cpp[System.Drawing.Drawing2D.ClassicLinearGradientBrush#1](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/m-system.drawing.drawing_18_1.cpp)] [!code-cs[System.Drawing.Drawing2D.ClassicLinearGradientBrush#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/m-system.drawing.drawing_18_1.cs)]

MemberSignature.Value: public System.Drawing.Drawing2D.ColorBlend InterpolationColors { get; set; }
.property instance class System.Drawing.Drawing2D.ColorBlend InterpolationColors

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a that defines a multicolor linear gradient.
Docs.value: A that defines a multicolor linear gradient.

remarks.format:
## Remarks A <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.ColorBlend> contains corresponding arrays of colors and positions. The positions are values from 0 through 1 that specify the percentage of the distance along the gradient line where the corresponding color is located.
Setting this property creates a multicolor gradient with one color at each position along the gradient line. Setting this property nullifies all previous color, position, and falloff settings for this <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.LinearGradientBrush>.

.property instance valuetype System.Drawing.Color[] LinearColors

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the starting and ending colors of the gradient.
Docs.value: An array of two structures that represents the starting and ending colors of the gradient.

remarks.format: ## Examples For an example, see <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.LinearGradientBrush.MultiplyTransform%2A>.

MemberSignature.Value: public void MultiplyTransform (System.Drawing.Drawing2D.Matrix matrix, System.Drawing.Drawing2D.MatrixOrder order);
.method public hidebysig instance void MultiplyTransform(class System.Drawing.Drawing2D.Matrix matrix, valuetype System.Drawing.Drawing2D.MatrixOrder order) cil managed

Docs.param: The by which to multiply the geometric transform.
A that specifies in which order to multiply the two matrices.
Docs.summary: Multiplies the that represents the local geometric transform of this by the specified in the specified order.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following code example is designed for use with Windows Forms, and it requires <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs>`e`, an <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form.OnPaint%2A> event object. The code performs the following actions:
- Creates a new <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.LinearGradientBrush>.
- Draws an ellipse to the screen using this brush.
- Calls the <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.LinearGradientBrush.MultiplyTransform%2A> method, to transform the <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.LinearGradientBrush>.
- Draws an ellipse to the screen directly below the first ellipse, using the transformed brush.
Notice that the lower ellipse is stretched in the horizontal direction, and that the gradient is stretched to match the new shape.
[!code-vb[System.Drawing.Drawing2D.ClassicLinearGradientBrush#2](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/90c76832-46c2-4578-8b9f-_1.vb)] [!code-cpp[System.Drawing.Drawing2D.ClassicLinearGradientBrush#2](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/90c76832-46c2-4578-8b9f-_1.cpp)] [!code-cs[System.Drawing.Drawing2D.ClassicLinearGradientBrush#2](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/90c76832-46c2-4578-8b9f-_1.cs)]

MemberSignature.Value: public System.Drawing.RectangleF Rectangle { get; }
.property instance valuetype System.Drawing.RectangleF Rectangle

Docs.summary: Gets a rectangular region that defines the starting and ending points of the gradient.
Docs.value: A structure that specifies the starting and ending points of the gradient.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The left side of the rectangle specifies the starting point of the linear gradient, and the right side of the rectangle specifies the endpoint.

MemberSignature.Value: public void ResetTransform ();
.method public hidebysig instance void ResetTransform() cil managed

Docs.summary: Resets the <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.LinearGradientBrush.Transform%2A> property to identity.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following code example is designed for use with Windows Forms, and it requires <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs>`e`, an <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form.OnPaint%2A> event object. The code performs the following actions:
- Creates a new <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.LinearGradientBrush>.
- Draws an ellipse to the screen using this brush.
- Calls the <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.LinearGradientBrush.MultiplyTransform%2A> method to transform the <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.LinearGradientBrush>.
- Draws an ellipse to the screen directly below the first ellipse, using the transformed brush.
- Resets the transform.
- Draws a third ellipse to the screen below the first two.
Notice that the lowest ellipse is drawn the same size as the first, and that, due to the call to the ResetTransform method, the gradient has been reduced to match.
[!code-vb[System.Drawing.Drawing2D.ClassicLinearGradientBrush#3](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/m-system.drawing.drawing_6_1.vb)] [!code-cpp[System.Drawing.Drawing2D.ClassicLinearGradientBrush#3](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/m-system.drawing.drawing_6_1.cpp)] [!code-cs[System.Drawing.Drawing2D.ClassicLinearGradientBrush#3](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/m-system.drawing.drawing_6_1.cs)]

.method public hidebysig instance void RotateTransform(float32 angle) cil managed

Docs.param: The angle of rotation.
Docs.summary: Rotates the local geometric transform by the specified amount. This method prepends the rotation to the transform.

remarks.format: ## Examples For an example, see <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.LinearGradientBrush.RotateTransform%2A>.

MemberSignature.Value: public void RotateTransform (float angle, System.Drawing.Drawing2D.MatrixOrder order);
.method public hidebysig instance void RotateTransform(float32 angle, valuetype System.Drawing.Drawing2D.MatrixOrder order) cil managed

Docs.param: The angle of rotation.
A that specifies whether to append or prepend the rotation matrix.
Docs.summary: Rotates the local geometric transform by the specified amount in the specified order.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following code example is designed for use with Windows Forms, and it requires <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs>`e`, an <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form.OnPaint%2A> event object. The code
- Creates a new <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.LinearGradientBrush>.
- Draws an ellipse to the screen using this brush.
- Rotates the <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.LinearGradientBrush> 45 degrees by calling the <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.LinearGradientBrush.RotateTransform%2A> method.
- Draws an ellipse to the screen directly below the first ellipse, using the rotated brush.
Notice that the gradient of the lower ellipse is at a 45 degree angle to the x-axis of the top ellipse. Also notice that a call to the <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.LinearGradientBrush.TranslateTransform%2A> method is used to justify the left edge of the gradient fill with the left edge of the lower ellipse.
[!code-vb[System.Drawing.Drawing2D.ClassicLinearGradientBrush#4](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/6302de64-3f75-4fc9-b2c4-_1.vb)] [!code-cpp[System.Drawing.Drawing2D.ClassicLinearGradientBrush#4](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/6302de64-3f75-4fc9-b2c4-_1.cpp)] [!code-cs[System.Drawing.Drawing2D.ClassicLinearGradientBrush#4](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/6302de64-3f75-4fc9-b2c4-_1.cs)]

The amount by which to scale the transform in the y-axis direction.

remarks.format: ## Examples For an example, see <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.LinearGradientBrush.ScaleTransform%2A>.

MemberSignature.Value: public void ScaleTransform (float sx, float sy, System.Drawing.Drawing2D.MatrixOrder order);
.method public hidebysig instance void ScaleTransform(float32 sx, float32 sy, valuetype System.Drawing.Drawing2D.MatrixOrder order) cil managed

Docs.param: The amount by which to scale the transform in the x-axis direction.
The amount by which to scale the transform in the y-axis direction.
A that specifies whether to append or prepend the scaling matrix.
Docs.summary: Scales the local geometric transform by the specified amounts in the specified order.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following code example is designed for use with Windows Forms, and it requires <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs>`e`, an <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form.OnPaint%2A> event object. The code performs the following actions:
- Creates a new <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.LinearGradientBrush>.
- Draw an ellipse to the screen using this brush.
- Scales the <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.LinearGradientBrush> by a factor of two in the x-axis.
- Draws an ellipse to the screen directly below the first ellipse, using the scaled brush.
Notice that the gradient of the lower ellipse is stretched by a factor of two. Also notice that a call to the <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.LinearGradientBrush.TranslateTransform%2A> method is used to justify the left edge of the gradient fill with the left edge of ellipse.
[!code-vb[System.Drawing.Drawing2D.ClassicLinearGradientBrush#5](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/e0c3e704-6b4f-48bc-83d2-_1.vb)] [!code-cpp[System.Drawing.Drawing2D.ClassicLinearGradientBrush#5](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/e0c3e704-6b4f-48bc-83d2-_1.cpp)] [!code-cs[System.Drawing.Drawing2D.ClassicLinearGradientBrush#5](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/e0c3e704-6b4f-48bc-83d2-_1.cs)]

MemberSignature.Value: public void SetBlendTriangularShape (float focus);
.method public hidebysig instance void SetBlendTriangularShape(float32 focus) cil managed

Docs.param: A value from 0 through 1 that specifies the center of the gradient (the point where the gradient is composed of only the ending color).
Docs.summary: Creates a linear gradient with a center color and a linear falloff to a single color on both ends.

remarks.format:
## Remarks This method specifies a `focus`, which is the point where the gradient is composed only of the ending color. The `focus` parameter represents a location as a proportion of the distance along the gradient line. The gradient falls off to the starting color linearly to either side.
## Examples For an example, see <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.LinearGradientBrush.SetBlendTriangularShape%2A>.

MemberSignature.Value: public void SetBlendTriangularShape (float focus, float scale);
.method public hidebysig instance void SetBlendTriangularShape(float32 focus, float32 scale) cil managed

Docs.param: A value from 0 through 1 that specifies the center of the gradient (the point where the gradient is composed of only the ending color).
A value from 0 through1 that specifies how fast the colors falloff from the starting color to `focus` (ending color)
Docs.summary: Creates a linear gradient with a center color and a linear falloff to a single color on both ends.

remarks.format:
## Remarks This method specifies a `focus`, which is the point where the gradient is composed only of the ending color. The `focus` parameter represents a location as a proportion of the distance along the gradient line. The gradient falls off to the starting color linearly to either side.
## Examples The following code example is designed for use with Windows Forms, and it requires <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs>`e`, an <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form.OnPaint%2A> event object. The code performs the following actions:
- Creates a new <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.LinearGradientBrush>.
- Uses this brush to draw an ellipse to the screen that has a linear, left-to-right transition of colors.
- Transforms the <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.LinearGradientBrush> into a triangular shape with its peak in the center.
- Draws a second ellipse to the screen using the transformed brush.
Notice that the gradient of the lower ellipse transitions from blue to red and then back to blue.
[!code-vb[System.Drawing.Drawing2D.ClassicLinearGradientBrush#6](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/e6c3d0c9-aed2-4364-946f-_1.vb)] [!code-cpp[System.Drawing.Drawing2D.ClassicLinearGradientBrush#6](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/e6c3d0c9-aed2-4364-946f-_1.cpp)] [!code-cs[System.Drawing.Drawing2D.ClassicLinearGradientBrush#6](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/e6c3d0c9-aed2-4364-946f-_1.cs)]

MemberSignature.Value: public void SetSigmaBellShape (float focus);
.method public hidebysig instance void SetSigmaBellShape(float32 focus) cil managed

Docs.param: A value from 0 through 1 that specifies the center of the gradient (the point where the starting color and ending color are blended equally).
Docs.summary: Creates a gradient falloff based on a bell-shaped curve.

remarks.format:
## Remarks This method specifies a `focus`, which is the point where the gradient is composed only of the ending color. The `focus` parameter represents a location as a proportion of the distance along the gradient line. The gradient falls off to the starting color based on a bell curve shape (normal distribution) to either side.
## Examples For an example, see <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.LinearGradientBrush.SetSigmaBellShape%2A>`.`

MemberSignature.Value: public void SetSigmaBellShape (float focus, float scale);
.method public hidebysig instance void SetSigmaBellShape(float32 focus, float32 scale) cil managed

Docs.param: A value from 0 through 1 that specifies the center of the gradient (the point where the gradient is composed of only the ending color).
A value from 0 through 1 that specifies how fast the colors falloff from the `focus`.
Docs.summary: Creates a gradient falloff based on a bell-shaped curve.

remarks.format:
## Remarks This method specifies a `focus`, which is the point where the gradient is composed only of the ending color. The `focus` parameter represents a location as a proportion of the distance along the gradient line. The gradient falls off to the starting color based on a bell curve shape (normal distribution) to either side.
## Examples The following code example is designed for use with Windows Forms, and it requires <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs>`e`, an <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form.OnPaint%2A> event object. The code performs the following actions:
- Creates a new <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.LinearGradientBrush>.
- Uses this brush to draw an ellipse to the screen that has a linear, left-to-right transition of colors.
- Transforms the <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.LinearGradientBrush> to have a bell shaped curve with its peak in the center.
- Draws a second ellipse to the screen using the bell-shaped brush.
Notice that the gradient of the lower ellipse transitions from blue to red and then back to blue.
[!code-vb[System.Drawing.Drawing2D.ClassicLinearGradientBrush#7](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/06854fcf-f315-4b99-b3db-_1.vb)] [!code-cpp[System.Drawing.Drawing2D.ClassicLinearGradientBrush#7](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/06854fcf-f315-4b99-b3db-_1.cpp)] [!code-cs[System.Drawing.Drawing2D.ClassicLinearGradientBrush#7](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/06854fcf-f315-4b99-b3db-_1.cs)]

MemberSignature.Value: public System.Drawing.Drawing2D.Matrix Transform { get; set; }
.property instance class System.Drawing.Drawing2D.Matrix Transform

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a copy that defines a local geometric transform for this .
Docs.value: A copy of the that defines a geometric transform that applies only to fills drawn with this .

remarks.format: ## Remarks A geometric transform can be used to translate, scale, rotate, or skew the gradient fill. Because the matrix returned and by the Transform property is a copy of the brush's geometric transform, you should dispose of the matrix when you no longer need it.

Docs.param: The value of the translation in x.
The value of the translation in y.
The order (prepend or append) in which to apply the translation.
Docs.summary: Translates the local geometric transform by the specified dimensions in the specified order.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following code example is designed for use with Windows Forms, and it requires <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs>`e`, an <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form.OnPaint%2A> event object. The code performs the following actions:
- Creates a new <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.LinearGradientBrush>.
- Uses this brush to draw a rectangle to the screen that has a linear, left-to-right transition of colors.
- Rotates the <xref:System.Drawing.Drawing2D.LinearGradientBrush> by 90 degrees and scales the gradient.
- Draws the rectangle, with the rotated and scaled gradient, to the screen.
- Translates the rectangle so that it has a linear gradient running from top to bottom.
- Draws the translated rectangle to the screen.
Notice that there are three rectangles displayed the top one showing the left-to-right gradient, the middle one showing the rotated and scaled gradient, and the bottom one showing the final, translated gradient.
[!code-vb[System.Drawing.Drawing2D.ClassicLinearGradientBrush#8](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/245473a1-ce62-4749-b877-_1.vb)] [!code-cpp[System.Drawing.Drawing2D.ClassicLinearGradientBrush#8](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/245473a1-ce62-4749-b877-_1.cpp)] [!code-cs[System.Drawing.Drawing2D.ClassicLinearGradientBrush#8](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/245473a1-ce62-4749-b877-_1.cs)]

MemberSignature.Value: public System.Drawing.Drawing2D.WrapMode WrapMode { get; set; }
.property instance valuetype System.Drawing.Drawing2D.WrapMode WrapMode

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a enumeration that indicates the wrap mode for this .
Docs.value: A that specifies how fills drawn with this are tiled.
